author: @sixtyblackmystictraveler
text:
59:56 You see how magic works?? I tuned in to listen to some interesting analysis on a topic I know ABSOLUTELY NOTHING about (hip hop, its main characters or history even though I lived through its creative cycle) and the conversation involves into some real talk about how to not turn away from the ugliness in ourselves and how we project onto others in the form of abuse by our family members, friends to us and to others. I have a brother who is an abuser multiple times multiple ways. He has trauma he hasn‚Äôt chosen to address and it spills ALL OVER his life and relationships. He was my protector, my teacher when I was little and I don‚Äôt like who he has become and won‚Äôt pretend at all it‚Äôs cool with me. My mother 83 Christian wants to believe if we just love him and appreciate him more and not talk about the consequences of his abuse on the women and children who are in early adulthood now one has tried to commit suicide, there‚Äôs addiction, self-negation behaviors but we supposed to see that as just normal family shit. It‚Äôs US humans that normalized it doing the best we could with the information we have. My thing is the INFORMATION is there. It‚Äôs widely talked about therapy, trauma therapy, nervous system dysregulation, generational trauma‚Ä¶.and whether you choose or don‚Äôt encounter never heard of it like me until 2020, we are still responsible for blowing our shit into other people‚Äôs and psyches. Someone has to start. Just one. To start. And we can all liberate ourselves and show others it is possible. Violence is a choice but we haven‚Äôt been able to make the choice because of the water we swim in. 

Thank you all for the work you do in your lives and on this medium. This soon to be 61 year old is learning so much from your perspectives. We are people who have been abused for so long that numbing means abusing the next generation. May we know we CAN stop. Healing is possible.

author: @Purple_Haz373
text: This is a much needed and great conversation. I am a big fan of Kendrick, but even I have been bothered for years about who HE hangs out with. He can talk all he wants to about Drake and what Drake has allegedly done and who Drake hangs out with. But, really, it‚Äôs a widespread problem in hip-hop and throughout the culture, if I‚Äôm being honest. The problem I have with this discussion is that it felt like Kendrick and Drake are being scapegoated for a larger problem that we have. If we are going to hold these moral standards when it comes to both men and Dr. Dre, Kodak Black, Baka, etc. then hip-hop is in HUGE trouble. We need to hold them ALL accountable. In other words, we‚Äôre all hypocrites. All of us. No one on this panel will stop supporting Drake or Kendrick. No one on this panel will stop supporting many of these hip-hop artists, most of them who mistreat women, are deadbeat dads, engage in acts of violence, etc. Maybe hip-hop needs to die because the misogynior is never going away until we hold them all accountable. Thanks for this discussion. I hope that as much outrage shown towards Kendrick and Drake, Dre and Kodak, that outrage will be transferred to all of these problematic rappers and the culture in general. If ya‚Äôll continue to support Chris Brown, Future and 50 Cent and others, then I don‚Äôt see progress being made at all. HOLD THEM ALL ACCOUNTABLE‚Äînot just those we don‚Äôt like.

I think/ feel a point was missed in this discussion. For all of us to say this concert was beautiful and amazing, we have to forget that a lot of people on that stage probably have the same cases as Dr Dre. We should be having the same feelings for all of them.

author: @skydivemag8718
text:
I think you guys had a great discussion here. 

I would like to point out one thing that was missed here when it comes to the context around Kendrick's approach to his subject matter & content in his music.

Kendrick does not position himself as a moral authority in a general sense. I think people ascribe that to him simply because he addresses topics that are rarely addressed in hip hop music.

Rather Kendrick positions himself as a human with human experiences and often honestly and purposefully portrays his hypocritical and contradictory ways.

Think the last 2 bars of The Blacker The Berry in 2015 all the way up to Mr. Morale album where he addresses sexual abuse but then also has Kodak Black (noteworthy for his abuse case) sort of host the album and even calls himself Kodak Black.

Now go listen to Prayer by Kendrick Lamar where he says "I can't help we jump in these bodies and you call them a God/ just know the earth is just a rock without the voices of art".

This all shows that Kendrick does approach this hypocrisy within himself, his music, and the world with much forethought. But rather it's from a human perspective and not a morally superior perspective.

I think what he's trying to say is this, we all deal with this world and ourselves as flawed and we have to look in the mirror and struggle with that. Maybe there is no perfect solution as we're all imperfect human beings. But the best thing we can do is be human through it all. Make your mistakes, don't hide them and hold yourself accountable.

I prob didn't break that down the best way but I just wanted to show how I think Kendrick does approach his art with alot of what you guys discussed in mind.

text: What I think is missing from a lot of these DV conversations is the other side of that coin, which is a woman‚Äôs role in the DV situation because it absolutely goes both ways.
